summary: Fall of the Western Roman Empire
description: The Western Roman Empire collapsed, marking the end of ancient Roman rule in Europe. This event had profound and lasting impacts on the political, cultural, and social landscape of the continent.
Magna Carta was issued in June 1215 and was the first document to put into writing the principle that the king and his government was not above the law.
Christopher Columbus, an Italian explorer, sponsored by Spain, arrived in the Americas. This event marked the beginning of European exploration and colonization in the New World.

The East India Company was an English, and later British, joint-stock company founded in 1600 and dissolved in 1874. It was formed to trade in the Indian Ocean region, initially with the East Indies, and later with East Asia.

Nicolas Copernicus, a Polish mathematician and astronomer, published 'De revolutionibus orbium coelestium,' providing evidence for a heliocentric solar system where the Earth revolves around the Sun. This challenged the geocentric model and laid the groundwork for modern astronomy.

The traditional date for the foundation of the United Kingdom is May 1, 1707, when the Kingdom of Great Britain was formed through the political union of the Kingdom of England and the Kingdom of Scotland.

The Continental Congress adopted the Declaration of Independence, proclaiming the thirteen American colonies as independent states. This event marked the birth of the United States and the pursuit of self-governance.

Elected as the first President of the United States, George Washington played a crucial role in the founding of the nation. His leadership during the American Revolutionary War and his commitment to a strong central government were instrumental in shaping the early republic.

The French Revolution commenced with the storming of the Bastille, leading to widespread social and political upheaval in France. This event marked the end of absolute monarchy and the rise of democratic ideals.

As the principal author of the Declaration of Independence, Thomas Jefferson became the third President of the United States. His presidency is notable for the Louisiana Purchase, which doubled the size of the country, and the Lewis and Clark Expedition.
Series of wars that ranged France against shifting alliances of European powers

On February 21, 1804, British mining engineer, inventor and explorer Richard Trevithick debuted the first full-scale working railway steam locomotive in the Welsh mining town of Merthyr Tydfil. Following that debut, locomotives have been powered by a myriad of fuels, including wood, coal and oil.

President Elected as the seventh President, Andrew Jackson was a populist leader and a military hero. His presidency is marked by the expansion of suffrage and the controversial Indian Removal Act, leading to the Trail of Tears.

summary: The Indian Removal Act was signed
description: The Indian Removal Act was signed into law on May 28, 1830, by United States President Andrew Jackson. The law, as described by Congress, provided "for an exchange of lands with the Native Americans residing in any of the states or territories, and for their removal west of the river Mississippi

Beyond the health problems related to opium addiction, the increasing opium trade with the Western powers meant that for the first time, China imported more goods than it exported. Settling this financial problem eventually led to the First Opium War between Great Britain and China
an invasion of Mexico by the United States Army from 1846 to 1848.
when gold was found by James W. Marshall at Sutter's Mill in Coloma, California. The news of gold brought approximately 300,000 people to California from the rest of the United States and abroad
The Crimean War was fought from October 1853 to February 1856 between Russia and an ultimately victorious alliance of the Ottoman Empire, France, the United Kingdom and Sardinia-Piedmont.
The Indian Rebellion of 1857 was a major uprising in India in 1857–58 against the rule of the British East India Company, which functioned as a sovereign power on behalf of the British Crown

summary: Darwin's 'On the Origin of Species' Published
description: Charles Darwin, an English naturalist, published his groundbreaking work 'On the Origin of Species,' introducing the theory of evolution by natural selection. This revolutionized biological science, challenging traditional views on the origin and diversity of species.

Abraham Lincoln, the 16th President, led the nation through the Civil War, preserving the Union and issuing the Emancipation Proclamation, which ultimately led to the abolition of slavery in the United States.

What led to the outbreak of the bloodiest conflict in the history of North America? A common explanation is that the Civil War was fought over the moral issue of slavery. In fact, it was the economics of slavery and political control of that system that was central to the conflict. A key issue was states' rights.

Karl Marx, a German philosopher and economist, published "Das Kapital," a seminal work in political economy. The book critically analyzes capitalism, its economic processes, and the exploitation of labor, laying the theoretical groundwork for Marxist thought.
the British North America Act created a confederation from three colonies (Nova Scotia, New Brunswick, and Canada) called the Dominion of Canada.

summary: Abolition of Slavery in the United States
description: The 13th Amendment to the U.S. Constitution was ratified, officially abolishing slavery in the United States. While this marked a significant legal victory, systemic racism persisted in various forms.
The political revolution in 1868 that brought about the final demise of the Tokugawa shogunate (military government)—thus ending the Edo (Tokugawa) period (1603–1867)

The Suez Canal is an artificial sea-level waterway in Egypt, connecting the Mediterranean Sea to the Red Sea through the Isthmus of Suez and dividing Africa and Asia. The 193.30 km long canal is a key trade route between Europe and Asia.

European powers convened in Berlin to discuss and formalize the partitioning of Africa. The conference resulted in the arbitrary drawing of borders without considering ethnic, cultural, or geographical realities, leading to lasting consequences for African nations.

summary: New Zealand Grants Women the Right to Vote
description: Although a number of other territories enfranchised women before 1893, New Zealand can justly claim to be the first self-governing country to grant the vote to all adult women.
From 1897 to 1910, Japan step by step tightened control, finally ending the Joseon Dynasty in 1910 with the Japan-Korea Annexation Treaty.
Austria-Hungary declares war on Serbia, beginning World War I.
Revolution that overthrew the imperial government and placed the Bolsheviks in power
Germany surrendered because they were unable to sustain the way much longer

summary: Women gaining the right to vote in US

description: Vladimir Ilyich Ulyanov, better known as Vladimir Lenin, was a Russian revolutionary, politician, and political theorist. He served as the first and founding head of government of Soviet Russi
The collapse of world trade due to the Smoot-Hawley Tariff; government policies; bank failures and panics; and the collapse of the money supply
The forced relocation of Native American tribes, including the Cherokee, Choctaw, and others, by the U.S. government resulted in thousands of deaths due to exposure, disease, and starvation.

Elected during the Great Depression, Franklin D. Roosevelt implemented the New Deal, a series of programs and policies to address economic challenges. He also led the country through most of World War II.
military revolt against the Republican government of Spain, supported by conservative elements within the country
Nazi Germany and Imperial Japan unleashed World War II with the intention of establishing, by military conquest, a permanent dominance over Europe and Asia respectively.
Ho Chi Minh, leader of the Viet Minh, declares independence from French colonial rule as he announces the formation of the Democratic Republic of Vietnam.
The United Nations was established in the aftermath of World War II to promote international cooperation, peace, and security among nations.
the United States detonated two atomic bombs over the Japanese cities of Hiroshima and Nagasaki respectively.
In 1945, Korea was finally liberated from its occupation, and exactly three years later, on August 15th, 1948, the Republic of Korea was officially established.

The Cambodian genocide was the systematic persecution and killing of intellectuals along with some religious and ethnic minorities in Cambodia by the Khmer Rouge under the leadership of Communist Party of Kampuchea general secretary Pol Pot.

British India was divided into two independent nations, India and Pakistan, based on religious lines. The partition resulted in the creation of the Islamic Republic of Pakistan and the secular Republic of India.
NATO was formed as a military alliance for collective defense against external aggression, providing security and cooperation among its member countries.

keywords: 20th Century, China, People's Republic of China
description: The Chinese Communist Party, led by Mao Zedong, proclaimed the establishment of the People's Republic of China (PRC) on October 1, 1949, following the victory of the Communists in the Chinese Civil War.
North Korea aimed to militarily conquer South Korea and therefore unify Korea under the communist North Korean regime

summary: Civil Rights Movement started in US
description: The U.S. Supreme Court ruled unanimously that “separate educational facilities are inherently unequal,” legally ending racial segregation in public schools and overruling the “separate but equal” principle set forth in Plessy v. Ferguson in 1889.

Dwight D. Eisenhower, a five-star general during World War II, became the 34th President of the United States. His presidency is known for the implementation of the Interstate Highway System and a focus on Cold War diplomacy.

The Geneva Conference divided Vietnam at the 17th parallel, with the North controlled by the communists under Ho Chi Minh and the South by anti-communist forces. The conference aimed to temporarily resolve the Indochina conflict and pave the way for national elections.
John F. Kennedy's presidency is known for the Cuban Missile Crisis and the establishment of the Peace Corps. He advocated for civil rights and set the goal of landing a man on the moon.

also known as the October Crisis in Cuba, or the Missile Scare, was a 13-day confrontation between the United States and the Soviet Union, when American deployments of nuclear missiles in Italy and Turkey were matched by Soviet deployments of nuclear missiles in Cuba.

summary: Martin Luther King Jr.'s "I Have a Dream" Speech
description: Martin Luther King Jr. delivered his iconic "I Have a Dream" speech during the March on Washington. The speech advocated for racial equality and became a powerful symbol of the Civil Rights Movement.

Singapore previously had been under the sovereignty of the British Empire since the early 19th century. After gaining its independence from the British Empire in 1963, Singapore briefly joined the Federation of Malaysia, before breaking away for independent sovereignty in 1965.

summary: U.S. Involvement in the Vietnam War
description: The United States officially committed ground troops to the Vietnam War, escalating its involvement in the conflict. This marked a significant turning point as American military presence increased to support South Vietnam against the communist North.
Civil rights activist Malcolm X was assassinated. His advocacy for black empowerment and critique of systemic racism left a lasting impact on the struggle for racial justice.

Richard Nixon served as the 37th President, known for his foreign policy initiatives, including the normalization of relations with China and the end of U.S. involvement in the Vietnam War. However, his presidency was also marked by the Watergate scandal, leading to his resignation.
Formally known as the Great Proletarian Cultural Revolution, was a sociopolitical movement in the People's Republic of China launched by Mao Zedong
Astronauts Neil Armstrong and Edwin “Buzz” Aldrin became the first men to walk on the moon after reaching the surface in their Apollo 11 lunar module.

summary: Forced Sterilization of Native American women started
keywords: While the limited count by the GAO represents a minimum, studies have accused the IHS of sterilizing between 25-50% of Native American women from 1970 to 1976. Should the highest estimate be accurate, up to 70,000 women may have been sterilized over the period.
description: 20th Century, North America

summary: Fall of Saigon(The end of the Vietnam War)
description: North Vietnamese forces captured Saigon, the capital of South Vietnam, leading to the end of the Vietnam War. The event marked the reunification of North and South Vietnam under communist control.
five days after half a million people gathered in East Berlin in a mass protest
international conflict that was triggered by Iraq's invasion of Kuwait

Gorbachev's decision to allow elections with a multi-party system and create a presidency for the Soviet Union began a slow process of democratization that eventually destabilized Communist control and contributed to the collapse of the Soviet Union.

The genocide against the Tutsi erupted in Rwanda, with neighbors turning on neighbors and family turning on family. Over 800,000 people — up to 1 million on some accounts — were brutally slaughtered in just 100 days, leaving the once-beautiful country in ruins.

summary: End of Apartheid in South Africa
description: Nelson Mandela was elected as the first black president of South Africa, marking the end of apartheid. Mandela's presidency symbolized a new era of racial reconciliation and equality in the country.

summary: The last residential school closed in Canada
description: The residential school system officially operated from the 1880s into the closing decades of the 20th century. The system forcibly separated children from their families for extended periods of time and forbade them to acknowledge their Indigenous heritage and culture or to speak their own languages.The Gordon Residential School in Punnichy, Saskatchewan, closed in 1996. It was the last federally-funded residential school in Canada.
This event ended 156 years of British rule in the former colony.
four coordinated Islamist suicide terrorist attacks carried out by al-Qaeda against the United States in 2001
U.S. and allied forces invaded the country and quickly ousted the Taliban regime following its refusal to hand over terrorist leader Osama bin Laden in the wake of al-Qaeda's 9/11 attacks.

the International Astronomical Union (IAU) downgraded the status of Pluto to that of "dwarf planet." This means that from now on only the rocky worlds of the inner Solar System and the gas giants of the outer system will be designated as planets.
wave of pro-democracy protests and uprisings that took place in the Middle East and North Africa
The founder and first leader of the Islamist militant group al-Qaeda, was shot and killed at his compound in the Pakistani city of Abbottabad by United States Navy SEALs of SEAL Team Six (
Many Syrians were complaining about high unemployment, corruption and a lack of political freedom under President Bashar al-Assad, who succeeded his father, Hafez
Russia invaded the Crimean Peninsula, part of Ukraine, and then annexed it.
A series of demonstrations against the Hong Kong government's introduction of a bill to amend the Fugitive Offenders Ordinance in regard to extradition.

George Perry Floyd Jr. was an African-American man who was murdered by a police officer in Minneapolis, Minnesota, during an arrest made after a store clerk suspected Floyd may have used a counterfeit twenty-dollar bill
two months after the defeat of U.S. president Donald Trump in the presidential election, a mob of his supporters attacked the United States Capitol Building in Washington, D.C
An armed conflict broke out between Israel and Hamas-led Palestinian militants from the Gaza Strip after the latter launched a multi-pronged invasion of southern Israel.
